Data: The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet provides advice and support to the Prime Minister, the Cabinet, Cabinet committee chairs, the Portfolio Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries and the Government as a whole. Data: The quality and coherence of regulation is maintained through whole of government co ordination, including through the Cabinet process.  In addition, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel provides consistency in the drafting of primary and secondary legislation.  The Office of Best Practice Regulation (transferred from the Department of Finance to PM&C on 18 September 2013) assists government departments and agencies to meet the Government‚Äôs requirements for best practice regulatory impact analysis, among other things.

Monitoring the implementation of government policy - what other body/part of government has or shares this responsibility
Data: The implementation of government policy is conducted by the relevant department or agency.  PM&C provides oversight and support, including through the Cabinet Implementation Unit (CIU) within PM&C.  An example is the CIU‚Äôs Australian Public Service Policy Implementation Network, which draws on members‚Äô experience to share knowledge and develop a culture of collaboration on implementation and delivery.  The Department of Finance also provides oversight through the Gateway Review Process.  This involves short, intensive reviews at critical points in a major project or program‚Äôs lifecycle to assess progress and identify areas requiring corrective action early.

Topics: Q2.2.2. Has the structure of the CoG (number and type of units) remained stable since 2008 or has it changed?
If it has changed, in what way has it changed?
Data: PM&C is responsive to the priorities of the Government of the day.  These priorities may require changes to the structure of the department.  The ‚Äòmatters dealt with‚Äô by each department are laid out in the Administrative Arrangements Orders (AAOs).  The current AAOs are available on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet website (http://www.dpmc.gov.au/parliamentary/index.cfm).  Earlier AAOs are available on the ComLaw website (http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Browse/ByDateOfMaking/AdministrativeArrangementsOrders/Historical/0/).

Data: As at 30 June 2012, the PMO had an allocation of 53 staff.  These staff range from secretarial or administrative staff to senior policy advisers (http://www.finance.gov.au/publications/mops_annual_reports/2011-2012/Content/14_employee_allocations_and_numbers.html).

Topics: Any further details on the Private Office
Data: The Prime Minister‚Äôs Office (PMO) is a private office that advises the Prime Minister directly.  It is not part of PM&C or the Australian Public Service.  Staff of ministerial offices are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 (http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2011C00285).

Relations with sub-national levels of government:PM&C leads the government‚Äôs relations with sub-national levels of government through its support for the Council of Australian Governments (COAG).  COAG is chaired by the Prime Minister and includes the first ministers of each Australian State and Territory and the head of the Australian Local Government Association.  The COAG system includes ministerial councils that facilitate consultation and cooperation among the levels of government.  Other departments and agencies may also engage with Australian States and Territories on specific issues.  Please note that the most important area of responsibility for PM&C is to provide advice to the Prime Minister.  In the table above PM&C has indicated the highest priority responsibilities from the options provided.

Topics: Q3.1.1. What are the principal channels through which the Head of Government (HG) discusses policy issues?
Please feel free to provide information on how these channels work
Data: The Prime Minister may discuss policy issues through a number of channels.  Two examples in which PM&C supports the Prime Minister‚Äôs discussions are:   1. Australian Governments make formal decisions through the Cabinet process.  The 7th edition of the Cabinet Handbook (http://www.dpmc.gov.au/parliamentary/index.cfm) describes the Cabinet as a council of senior ministers empowered by the Australian Government to take binding decisions on its behalf.  The Cabinet seeks to resolve disputes and build consensus around issues through discussion and consultation.  2. Where policy matters involve Australian States or Territories, the Prime Minister may discuss them through the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) (http://www.coag.gov.au/).  COAG is the peak intergovernmental forum in Australia and includes the Prime Minister, First Ministers of Australian States and Territories and the President of the Australian Local Government Association.

Topics: Q3.1.2. Is the CoG responsible for co-ordinating discussion of agenda items prior to discussion by the Cabinet?

Data: Coordination takes place through committees of Cabinet, attended by ministers, and the circulation of agenda items for ministerial, departmental and agency comment in advance of consideration by committees and the Cabinet.

Data: The Department‚Äôs social media strategy is not published online.  The strategy outlines staff responsibilities when dealing with corporate social media and includes advice on how to set up an account and the limits of appropriate use. Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: The Australian Government seeks to maintain trust in public institutions through the legal and governance frameworks within which the Australian Public Service (APS) operates (http://www.apsc.gov.au/aps-employment-policy-and-advice/legislationlegal-and-government-frameworks).  For example, the Public Service Act 1999 (http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2013C00310) contains the APS Values (s. 10), the APS Employment Principles (s. 10A) and the Code of Conduct (s. 13), which regulate the behaviour and hiring of APS employees.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions
Q3.6.1. Is the Centre responsible for organising cross-governmental policy co-ordination groups or committees?
If yes, at what level do these groups exist?

Data: PM&C encourages policy coordination across government departments.  This may involve leading inter departmental taskforces or supporting other departments to cooperate.

Topics: Q3.6.2. What other mechanisms are used by the CoG to ensure policy co-ordination (if any)?
Data: PM&C ensures policy coordination through whole of government consultation.  This includes the role of the central agencies (PM&C, the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance) in the Cabinet and Budget processes and through meetings of the Secretaries Board.  Further examples of PM&C‚Äôs role in ensuring policy coordination are mentioned in response to questions 3.1.1-3.1.5 and 3.8.1 above.

Topics: Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: The Public Service Act 1999 (http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2013C00310) states that the roles of Secretaries includes collaboration with other Secretaries and across the whole of Government to achieve government outcomes (s. 57(1)(b)) and that the Secretaries Board must work collaboratively and model leadership behaviours (s. 64(3)(e)).

The Public Service Act 1999 (http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2013C00310) states that the roles of Secretaries includes collaboration with other Secretaries and across the whole of Government to achieve government outcomes (s. 57(1)(b)) and that the Secretaries Board must work collaboratively and model leadership behaviours (s. 64(3)(e)).

Topics: Q3.6.6. How much influence can the CoG exert over line ministries to encourage them to coordinate with each other?
Q3.7.1. Through what mechanisms does the CoG ensure that government policies are implemented by line ministries?

Data: The Cabinet forward schedule sets deadlines for ministers to bring forward proposals.  PM&C then monitors implementation through regular reports to the Cabinet on its key priorities. The Cabinet Implementation Unit (CIU), within PM&C, is responsible for monitoring the implementation of Cabinet priorities.  The CIU works with departments to ensure that comprehensive implementation plans and delivery advice are developed for all complex and challenging policy proposals.  The CIU also helps departments to access implementation and delivery expertise and skills across the Australian Public Service (APS) through:≠	- the APS Policy Implementation Network;≠	- a quarterly implementation newsletter; and ≠	- implementation planning training.

Topics: Workplan for the implementation of the Government Programme that sets deadlines for ministries to prepare particular proposals
Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: PM&C‚Äôs participates in the senior officials level Development Effectiveness Steering Committee, which advises the Government on major official development assistance strategy and budget proposals, among other things.

Grateful if this could be reflect in any reporting on the results of this survey.Question 1: The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet‚Äôs (PM&C) organisation chart is available at www.dpmc.gov.au/about_pmc/org_structure.cfm.  PM&C‚Äôs strategic statement, which is not available online, provides the following guidance: What we do‚Ä¢	We support the Prime Minister, the Cabinet and our Portfolio Ministers by focusing on the Government‚Äôs strategic priorities, by supporting the efficient functioning of government and by promoting good governance and decision making. What we focus on‚Ä¢	Delivery of timely, clear and rigorous advice on priority issues.‚Ä¢	Nurturing an effective, respectful, durable network of relationships both within and outside of government.‚Ä¢	Recruiting, developing and retaining the best staff in the APS. How we do it.‚Ä¢	Focus on the Prime Minister ‚Äì recognising what is important and anticipating what will become important;‚Ä¢	Lead through collaboration across government and externally;‚Ä¢	Intervene selectively and influence what matters;‚Ä¢	Espouse good government and whole of government outcomes by working closely with departments; and ‚Ä¢	Support sound decision making through stewardship of government processes. Data: The formal competences of Austrian CoG as an administrative unit must appear to be rather poor. This assessment, as such, is correct, and mainly due to two reasons:a)	On federal level individual ministers have always enjoyed great autonomy; this fact is well known at OECD level (cf James/Ben-Gera, Comparative Analysis of Government Offices in OECD Countries, 21. 9. 2004, GOV/PGC/MPM/RD (2004), 1) and may be related to the traditional role of ministries not so much as centres of policy-shaping, but of supreme administrative authorities, in conjunction with the importance of the national fundamental right (enshrined in Article 83 (2) of the federal Constitution) that competences of all authorities have to be specified by law in a clear and non-ambiguous manner. During the last decades, however, the role of Austrian administration underwent a deep change, supreme administrative authorities having lost almost completely their former judicial tasks (which were transferred to independent administrative authorities, to administrative tribunals and, as of 1. January 2014, to administrative courts of first instance); it remains to be seen whether this change will result also in a reduction of ministerial autonomy.b)	Policy-shaping has always been considered to be the core privilege of policy-makers, not of the administration or its staff, i.e. civil servants lacking sufficient democratic legitimacy. Hence, also coherence of Governmental policies is to be maintained mainly on the political level. Changes in the political system (decrease of influence of the largest political parties) might, however, increase the need to strengthen the administrative structures in the field of policy-making (coordination and controlling of proper implementation included).

Q3.1.1. What are the principal channels through which the Head of Government (HG) discusses policy issues?
Please feel free to provide information on how these channels work
Data: Cabinet is the central decision-making body in Canada‚Äôs parliamentary system of government.  Cabinet is the Prime Minister‚Äôs forum for forging consensus and exercising leadership on the strategic directions and policies of the government. The policy committees of Cabinet are the mechanisms through which Ministers deliberate and make recommendations on policy issues.  Cabinet is currently structured under 6 committees and 1 sub-committee, as follows:--the Cabinet Committee on Priorities and Planning, which provides strategic direction on government priorities and expenditure management, ratifies committee recommendations and approves appointments;--the Cabinet Committee on Operations, which provides day-to-day coordination of the government‚Äôs agenda, including issues management, legislation and house planning, and communications;--the Treasury Board, which is responsible for accountability and ethics, financial, personnel and administrative management, comptrollership, approving regulations, and most Orders-in-Council;--the Treasury Board Sub-Committee on Government Administration, which considers proposals on whole-of-government opportunities for improved efficiency and effectiveness;--the Cabinet Committee on Social Affairs, which considers health care, justice, public safety, Aboriginal issues, training and skills development, culture, and immigration policy issues; --the Cabinet Committee on Economic Prosperity, which considers sectoral issues including international trade, sustainable development, natural resources, fisheries, agriculture, transport, infrastructure and communities, and regional development, as well as environment and energy security and other longer-term matters concerning Canada‚Äôs growth and economic prosperity; and--the Cabinet Committee on Foreign Affairs and Security, which considers foreign affairs, international development, public and national security, and defence policy issues.Direct bilateral contacts: The Prime Minister meets on a routine basis with the Clerk, Ministers, other heads of government including provincial Premiers, and other stakeholders.Group of advisors: The Prime Minister is also advised by advisory committees, such as the Prime Minister‚Äôs Advisory Committee on the Public Service, focussed on enhancing professionalism and efficiency in Canada‚Äôs public service.

Any further comments on social media and CoG
Data: The CoG does not have an overarching social media strategy.  Strategies are developed on a department by department basis, within the framework of Treasury Board Secretariat guidelines on social media and web use that departments are advised to follow, such as:Standard on Social Media Account Managementhttp://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?section=text&id=27033Guideline for External Use of Web 2.0http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?id=24835&section=textPolicy on Acceptable Network and Device Use (effective October 1, 2013)http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?section=text&id=27122 As a department, the CoG is responsible for the social media plans associated with the following websites:‚Ä¢	Economic Action Plan (www.actionplan.gc.ca);‚Ä¢	Prime Minister‚Äôs website (www.pm.gc.ca ); ‚Ä¢	Clerk‚Äôs website (www.clerk.gc.ca ).Please see the ‚ÄúAdditional Comments‚Äù section for information on the new Deputy Minister Committee on Social Media and Policy Development.PCO was responsible for the establishment of a Deputy Minister Committee on Social Media and Policy Development in 2012, to consider the linkages between social media and policy-making, including new models of policy development and public engagement and the role of the public servant in the social media sphere.  The committee held its first meeting in January 2013, and agreed that its operations would embody the open and interactive intent of social media.  The committee posts its agenda, discussion papers, meeting summaries, and additional resources on an internal government wiki, and committee members are paired with reverse mentors from their organizations who participate in the committee‚Äôs discussions and support its members in learning more about social media tools and platforms.The committee‚Äôs Twitter feed can be followed at @DM_SMPD.CoG staff fall under the guidelines for all civil servants established by the Treasury Board Secretariat; see:  http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?id=24835&section=text http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?section=text&id=27033http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?section=text&id=27122

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: Blueprint 2020PCO‚Äôs commitment to promoting excellence in the federal public service is an means of advancing the public interest ‚Äì i.e., to promote Canadians‚Äô trust that Canada‚Äôs public service will provide fearless advice and deliver sound programs and services.To this end, PCO recently launched the ‚ÄúBlueprint 2020 ‚Äì Getting Started ‚Äì Getting Your Views‚Äù process, which establishes a vision for the federal public service to continue to innovate and meet new standards of excellence to address the demands of the modern world.Four guiding principles will help to achieve ‚ÄúBlueprint 2020‚Äù:(1)	an open and networked environment that engages citizens and partners for the public good;(2)	a whole-of-government approach that enhances service delivery and value for money;(3)	a modern workplace that makes smart use of new technologies to improve networking, access to data and customer service; and(4)	a capable, confident and high-performing workforce that embraces new ways of working and mobilizing the diversity of talent to serve the country‚Äôs evolving needs.For additional information on ‚ÄúBlueprint 2020‚Äù, please see the following website:http://www.clerk.gc.ca/eng/feature.asp?pageId=350 Monitoring trustWith reference to question 3.5.1, PCO‚Äôs Public Opinion Research team (part of the Communications and Consultations secretariat) tracks existing opinion polls and publicly available data such as the Americas Barometer that is conducted in partnership with the Environics Institute, which measures (among other things) trust and confidence in public institutions.  There is, however, no ongoing effort to specifically monitor the issue of trust in government.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions
Q3.6.1. Is the Centre responsible for organising cross-governmental policy co-ordination groups or committees?
If yes, at what level do these groups exist?
Q3.6.2. What other mechanisms are used by the CoG to ensure policy co-ordination (if any)?
Data: Prime Ministerial level:PCO supports the Prime Minister in the periodic tasking of ministers regarding the management of specific issues and the pursuit of specific objectives for the government over given portions of its mandate.Cabinet level: PCO supports two Committees of Cabinet that have policy coordination responsibilities.  The responsibilities of the Cabinet Committee on Priorities and Planning include providing strategic direction on government priorities and expenditure management.  The Cabinet Committee on Operations provides day-to-day coordination of the government‚Äôs agenda. Public service level: PCO supports, via the Clerk as Chair, several Deputy Minister Committees with policy coordination responsibilities.  These include: the Coordinating Committee of Deputy Ministers, which serves as a forum for discussion of government policy and priorities and ensures coordination across the Deputy Minister Committees; the Committee of Senior Officials, which serves as the human resources committee for the senior executive cadre of the public service; the Board of Management and Renewal, which serves as a forum to discuss major management reforms and the renewal of the public service; and Deputy Ministers‚Äô Breakfast.  Further information on these committees can be found at:http://www.pco.gc.ca/index.asp?lang=eng&page=secretariats&sub=spsp-psps&doc=comm/mandat-eng.htm      At the working level, PCO works with departments to ensure policy coherence within the broader policy framework, so that Ministers have full information to make decisions.  This takes place through central agencies meetings (PCO, Treasury Board Secretariat, Finance) and inter-departmental meetings.  These meetings are typically attended at the director general level (line departments) and director level (PCO).

Topics: Q3.6.3. From 2008-2012, has the number of cross-ministerial policy initiatives
Q3.6.4. What is the role of the CoG in cross-ministerial initiatives?
Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: The performance management agreements of PCO‚Äôs senior management include the achievement of horizontal collaboration as a key management competency.In addition, PCO‚Äôs responsibility to promote policy coordination across departments flows from its role to support the Prime Minister in managing the broad government agenda, together with its role in support of Cabinet decision-making.

Topics: Q3.6.6. How much influence can the CoG exert over line ministries to encourage them to coordinate with each other?
Q3.7.1. Through what mechanisms does the CoG ensure that government policies are implemented by line ministries?

Data: Tasking regarding the management of specific issues and the pursuit of specific objectives for the government over given portions of its mandate is periodically carried out through correspondence between the Prime Minister and Ministers.  PCO subsequently monitors progress on these initiatives for use in providing advice to the Prime Minister on the government‚Äôs agenda and on specific issues.

Topics: Workplan for the implementation of the Government Programme that sets deadlines for ministries to prepare particular proposals
Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: The International Assistance Envelope (IAE) is a dedicated pool of resources that enables the Government of Canada to deploy its international assistance nimbly and responsively. The Federal Budget allocates IAE resources and allows for cross-government co-ordination and prioritization. The IAE is co-managed by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, International Development and Finance in close collaboration with PCO and the Treasury Board Secretariat, further contributing to cross-government co-ordination, coherence and discussion of international development and aid issues.  As well, there is a Deputy Minister Committee on Global Trends, Foreign Affairs and Defence Issues (GTFAD), which among other activities, examines the objectives and impact of policy interventions, including development assistance.

Topics: Q3.9.1. Please indicate where the co-ordination of relations with each supra- or international body is located.

Data: In close cooperation with the Department of Finance
Summit of the Americas Process; Commonwealth; Francophonie

Topics: Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: Generally, PCO‚Äôs role in international cooperation in these policy areas is an indirect one; that is, PCO does not interact directly with foreign governments to discuss, for instance, financial sector or tax policy. The responsibility for ensuring dialogue and maintaining relationships with foreign governments in such areas of policy resides with the Minister and department in the Government of Canada that oversees that relevant policy area. (Note that monetary policy is the responsibility of the Bank of Canada and PCO‚Äôs role is limited to briefing the head of the public service and the Prime Minister on monetary policy direction taken by the Bank.)That said, there are some Ministerial and departmental activities related to international cooperation and coordination (e.g., negotiating competition or tax treaties) that may require that Cabinet / the Prime Minister be informed, or Cabinet / the Prime Minister‚Äôs approval. In these cases, the appropriate briefing processes at PCO, as described elsewhere in this survey, may be triggered to support a decision by Cabinet or the Prime Minister.

In addition to the websites already indicated in this questionnaire, the following PCO-related links may be of interest:Clerk‚Äôs website:http://www.clerk.gc.ca/eng/index.asp http://www.clerk.gc.ca/fra/index.aspPCO‚Äôs 2013-14 Report on Plans and Priorities, which sets out an overview of PCO‚Äôs priorities and planning highlights for this fiscal year:http://www.pco.gc.ca/index.asp?lang=eng&page=information&sub=publications&doc=rpp/2013-2014/index-eng.htmTRANSITION PLANNING:PCO is responsible for transition planning between governments, during general elections or during changes of political leadership that result in a new Prime Minister taking office.  During these periods, PCO leads and coordinates a whole-of-government exercise to provide the incoming Prime Minister with comprehensive information and advice regarding the launch of a new government mandate, the formation of a new Cabinet, the opening of a new Parliament, the machinery of government, and strategic policy issues, among other decisions and issues.

Topics: Q2.2.2. Has the structure of the CoG (number and type of units) remained stable since 2008 or has it changed?
If it has changed, in what way has it changed?
Data: ‚Ä¢	The Presidential Delivery Unit was created in 2010 as part of the Ministry Secretary General of the Presidency. Besides, in March 2011 the Modernization and E-government Unit was created at the Ministry of the Presidency. Similar units had been created before in some other ministries to treat this topic, nevertheless, since 2011, State¬¥s modernization is finally where it should be: at the centre of government, where comprehensive policies are designed towards the whole public administration.‚Ä¢	Some units, however, have been removed from its direct dependency of the centre of government, such as the Environment Commission, which was transferred to the Ministry of Environment, created in 2010. Senior services and native population issues were also transferred to a line ministry; in 2011, the just created Ministry of Social Development incorporated these two offices. Also the Food Safety Agency was transferred to the Ministry of Agriculture in 2011. Currently, the sport agency is part of the Secretary General of the Government, but there is a project presently being discussed to transform it into a new Ministry of Sport.

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: To improve efficiency and efficacy of the State, President Pi√±era¬¥s administration has created a one stop shop for public services (ChileAtiende), digitalized public procedures (Chile Sin Papeleo) and it has gradually implemented the e-payment of social services (ChileCuenta).To improve quality of attention towards users of public services, this administration has increased productivity in the public sector through reducing absenteeism and reducing the total payment of extra time. Besides, public payment time has been reduced thanks to ChilePaga program. Also, the Senior Public Official System was created in 2003. This system is created to professionalize high public positions. It watches over that top responsibilities are performed by competent and suitable professionals, selected by a transparent public tender. It has been increasing dramatically in terms on positions filled by this method.To increase transparency, integrity and citizen participation in State¬¥s administration, legal reforms have been made such as the creation in 2008 of the Integrity and Transparency Commission within the Ministry of the Presidency. Its mandate was to study foreign and local regulations about integrity, propose legal improvements about it, and support the implementation of the laws that are part of the Integrity and Transparency Agenda. Thinking of it as a long-term policy, a year later a Law of Transparency of the Public Administration was passed and a new institution was formed, the Council for Transparency, created to enforce this new law, and governed by a bipartisan board. A second measure regarding transparency was the bill sent to Congress in May 2011 about probity in public service. The object of this bill is to avoid possible conflicts of interest on the exercise of public service, incorporating norms relative to the declaration of assets and interests, trust deeds, and the transfer and use of assets. The honest performance of civil servants allows building a regime in which authorities work efficiently towards citizens. To improve regulation of lobby in Chile, a bill was sent in 2008 but had made little progress in Parliament towards approval and in 2012 President Pi√±era¬¥s administration sent several amendments to improve it. Today this reform is in the last stage of the legislative process. The objective of this initiative is to ensure transparency in public decisions, and that every stakeholder and public opinion may judge about impartiality, attributes and convenience of authorities decisions, without diminishing the necessary contact between the one that takes the decision and the ones affected by it. Finally, regarding public consultation, in Chile it is guided mainly by two laws: the Law about transparency from 2008 and the Law of citizen participation from 2011. Regarding the first one, the previously mentioned Council for Transparency works in increasing citizen information about government decisions. Regarding the second one, it says that before sending out any new regulations, the public institution should consult the pertinent stakeholders. In particular, public consultation is compulsory in regulations regarding small and medium enterprises and environment. Nevertheless, public consultations occur in areas such as international treaties, modernization of the State, and customs.

Government strategy is based on seven top priorities. One of them is improving Quality of Democracy, and some of its strategic objectives are: to improve citizen perception about its political institutions, increase quality of service, enhance government openness, and to promote a government closer to citizens. administration has created a one stop shop for public services (ChileAtiende), digitalized public procedures (Chile Sin Papeleo) and it has gradually implemented the e-payment of social services (ChileCuenta).To improve quality of attention towards users of public services, this administration has increased productivity in the public sector through reducing absenteeism and reducing the total payment of extra time. Besides, public payment time has been reduced thanks to ChilePaga program. Also, the Senior Public Official System was created in 2003. This system is created to professionalize high public positions.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions

Data: As a general basis, the Interministerial Coordination Division (ICD) is permanently fostering coordination towards results among line ministries.In addition, direct bilateral contacts are an effective coordination opportunity, since it brings together members from the Legal Division and the ICD from the Secretary General of the Presidency and people from the Budget Office, and from ‚ÄúPresidency‚Äù, besides the pertinent line minister or service director and the President itself.

Data: There are a series of initiatives that on the last years have been proven as successful measures:-	Improvement of the capacity of coordination, through standardization of ministerial committees.-	Improvement the public decision-making process through direct bilateral contacts between the President and the corresponding minister or chief of service.-	Implementation of the modernization agenda, coordinated by the Modernization Unit.-	Creation of the Presidential Delivery Unit, focused on results.-	Focus of the Centre of Government on its natural functions, gradually leaving aside line functions such as senior services and sports.We also carry some problems, such as the large amount of public employees, especially those of senior levels, that change with each change of government. Other problem is our broad definition of Centre of Government, since there are several ministries included in it and therefore responsibility is diluted.

Data: Most of the professional staff in the PMO is temporarily employed, typically on 2-3 year contracts. After their term in the PMO they normally continue their career in their native ministry.This recruitment strategy was established in the mid 1990‚Äôs. It was introduced to ensure a continuously dynamic and changing team of staff which possesses relevant expertise and analytical skills in different policy areas. In addition, having experts in the PMO with strong ties to the ministries and a thorough understanding of their areas enhances the CoG coordination processes.

Data: Adherence to the law on public management (Forvaltningsloven) and the law on access to public administration files (Offentlighedsloven), as well as promoting a transparent and accountable public administration in general is a fundamental principle. Maintaining trust in public institutions is a general objective. It has not been a target for specific initiatives or actions.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions

If yes, at what level do these groups exist?

Data: Also on the level of experts.

Data: Please refer to the answers to questions on Definition of the Centre of government (1.1.2 in paper copy) and Additional Comments for a description of some of the key mechanisms used.

Topics: Q3.6.3. From 2008-2012, has the number of cross-ministerial policy initiatives
Q3.6.4. What is the role of the CoG in cross-ministerial initiatives?
Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: Coordination objectives may feature in senior managers  performance related wage component.
Coordination is important to ensure Cabinet acceptance and implementation of initiatives. The Government takes decisions on the basis of processes to which all relevant ministries have contributed.

Topics: Q3.6.6. How much influence can the CoG exert over line ministries to encourage them to coordinate with each other?
Q3.7.1. Through what mechanisms does the CoG ensure that government policies are implemented by line ministries?

Data: Schemes that summarize the implementation status of each initiative in budget agreements and other major political agreements etc. The completion of the scheemes are coordinated by the Ministry of Finance with contributions from relevant line ministries.

Topics: Workplan for the implementation of the Government Programme that sets deadlines for ministries to prepare particular proposals
Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: Important international development and aid issues would in particular be coordinated in the permanent Coordination Committee and the Economic Committee. The development aid allocation is discussed annually in the Coordination Committee.

Topics: Q3.9.1. Please indicate where the co-ordination of relations with each supra- or international body is located.
Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: Important dossiers on international policy cooperation would in particular be coordinated in the permanent Coordination Committee and the Economic Committee.

Please also refer to the general description in the answer to question 1.1.2. Principal initiatives are generally initiated at the Government level (the Cabinet Committees) which set the direction of work, including the political discussions. In particular the permanent Coordination Committee and the Economic Committee are central in coordinating the work of the Government, but by no means exclusive. Important elements are also e.g. ministries with cross-responsibilities, cross-ministerial working groups on special initiatives from the Government and cross-ministerial publications, as well as seminars for ministers. At the level of permanent state secretaries, meetings and seminars are also important.

Topics: Q2.2.2. Has the structure of the CoG (number and type of units) remained stable since 2008 or has it changed?

Data: The organisational changes have diminished the number of entities (directorates and units).Net result of various reorganisations since 2008: 1 directorate and 1 unit (assigned to a directorate) lessMain changes in structure of the CoG since 2008: 01.04.2011:  - Rationalisation and consolidation: reduction by 1 directorate from 9 to currently 8 directorates.  The 3 units (and their staff) of the former directorate were transferred, according their specific activities to the other directorates.- Creation of a (temporary) Task Force for IT Governance01.09.2011:- merging of 2 units into 1 unit within a Directorate resulting in a reduction from 4 units to 3 in the Directorate.

Data: Preparation of Government Programme: The Secretariat General is in the lead on G8/G20 coordination and policy.  The European External Action Service leads on external relations, including coordination with the UN.  Regulatory quality and coherence: The Secretariat General has the overall horizontal policy responsibility for regulatory quality and coherence but other Directorate Generals are monitoring coherence of other policies with their respective policy areas. Monitoring the implementation of government policy: Each Directorate General monitors the implementation of their respective policies.  The Secretariat General is responsible for horizontal issues of implementation.  Relations with sub-national levels: The Secretariat General is the lead service on relations with subnational levels of government but each Directorate General is in contact in their respective policy areas. Relations with Parliament/Legislature: The Secretariat General is the lead service on relations with the European Parliament and national parliaments but each Directorate General is in contact with these institutions in their respective policy areas

Topics: Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: The Secretariat General is responsible for the G8 and G20 and plays a coordination role in regard to decisions on international cooperation on sectoral policies requiring internal coordination.  The lead is usually in the sector Directorate Generals (e.g. DG Economics and Finance, DG Environment etc)

The European Commission's Secretariat General has evolved from a coordinating body with a focus on procedures and registry/ reporting functions to a coordinating entity which provides policy direction and regulatory advice and scrutiny. This has entailed a major reorientation of strategic direction, replacement and recruitment of a different profile of professional staff and increased use of IT tools. The reform has taken a number of years to implement.

Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: Prime Minister¬¥s Office prepares the general guidelines of Finnish EU policy and coordinates preparation and handling of issues relating to the European Union in the ministries. The PMO is responsible for action relating to institutional questions and general development of the EU. It also considers issues concerning the amendment of basic treaties of the European Union. The PMO is also responsible for the preparation of European Council meetings and coordination of issues considered at the Council meetings.

Ministries in Finland have a high level of independence in their own respective policy fields. Prime Minister‚Äôs role can be described as ‚Äò primus inter pares‚Äô although changes in the Constitution have increased the role and responsibilities of the PM.  In order to overcome the problems in policy coordination between line ministries several initiatives are made to remove tasks from ministries to the PMO ‚Äì and some of them have materialized. During recent years there have been attempts to introduce mechanisms for better coordinated policies. Eg the presently used Strategic Impementation plan of the Government Programme is structured around three horizontal policy objectives, which are monitored annually based on data provided by COG. For two Gnt terms there were the concept of Government‚Äôs horizontal policy programmes in use (2003-2011).Evidence informed policymaking has been one of the mechanisms to strengthen coordination across Ministries e.g. by agreeing on indicators for the evaluation of progress in Government‚Äôs key policy areas. PMO promotes and develops these processes.The relationship between the coordination roles of the PMO and the Ministry of Finance responsible for the four-year and annual budget process has been strengthened but is still subject to further development.

Data: The main goal related to social media is to: transform the Cabinet Office‚Äôs (public facing) transactional services and online publishing. More specifically, a number of teams in the Cabinet Office are using social media and collaborative techniques for specific programmes. To identify exemplars, we will begin policy iteration exercises with users over the course of development in 2013 and we will begin a series of good practice seminars on using social media in the fourth quarter of 2013.

Data: Note that the Cabinet Office is responsible for all of the above (scenario planning, crisis co-ordination , identifying risks) yet the process of risk management is not considered ‚Äòdistinct‚Äô from strategic planning (as defined in this survey). The remit of the Civil Contingencies Secretariat, a team that sits within the Cabinet Office, falls into four main areas: risk assessment, preparation and planning, response and recovery, and building a resilient society.

Q3.7.1. Through what mechanisms does the CoG ensure that government policies are implemented by line ministries?

Data: Business Plans are the main tool used to track the performance of government departments. They include information on: departmental responsibilities; planned expenditure; input and impact indicators. All departmental business plans are available at http://transparency.number10.gov.uk/.The objectives of permanent secretaries, available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/permanent-secretaries-objectives-published-for-the-first-time, are a tool that is used to track individual performance. Corporate reports (including annual reports and accounts, progress reports, reviews etc.) are also used for monitoring performance.

Q3.9.1. Please indicate where the co-ordination of relations with each supra- or international body is located.

Data: Ministry of Defence is the lead department but it depends on the scope of work.
There are several departments involved depending on the scope of work: HM Treasury, FCO and Department for International Development.
Foreign Commonwealth Office (FCO) is the lead department but it depends on the scope of work.

Topics: Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: The European and Global Issues Team (a team that sits within the Cabinet Office) leads on coordinating international trade policy e.g. the WTO or bilateral trade agreements and tax agenda for the G8.

The Department for International Development is the lead department for aid. However, the European and Global Issues Secretariat (a team that sits in the Cabinet Office) is involved in EU international development work.Relevant publications that may be of use are: Cabinet Office Business Plan (2012-2015): https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cabinet-office-business-planThe Cabinet Office and the Centre of Government: http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200910/ldselect/ldconst/30/3002.htmThe Cabinet Manual: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cabinet-manual

Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: The financial insentives are very limited. Sometimes project are funded based on the pre-requisite that agencies work together.

There are limited, direct incentives to promote co-ordination at the ministerial level. The COG can make that case that if ministries work together on particular issue the matter will be supported by the PM. Most of the COG efforts around co-ordination is by promoting the values of more co-operation through regular meetings of permanent secretaries, meetings with law divisions of the ministries headed by the and other such coordination committees headed by the PMO.

Q1. Please indicate the Internet address (URL) of the organisation chart of your Centre of Government, as well as its mission statement, if these exist online.
Q1.1.1. Does the definition of the term Centre of Government used by this survey correspond to what is considered the ‚Äúcentre of government‚Äù in your country?
Q1.1.2. If your definition of the Centre of Government differs from the definition used in this survey, please explain the difference.
Data: Mission statement: The Italian ‚ÄúPresidency of the Council of Ministers‚Äù serves primarily the President of the Council. It also supports the Ministers without Portfolio and Under-Secretaries (delegated by the President of the Council). It is headed by the Secretary General. However, in our CoG definition (following the definition provided by this survey), we only consider those offices and departments of the ‚ÄúPresidency of the Council of Ministers‚Äù that support the collective work of the executive and the President, for the exercise of functions of coordination and political steering (e.g: Department of Regional Affairs, Department of European Policies, Government Program Office, etc.), or for legal, technical and managerial support. We also consider the Cabinet of the President, comprising the ‚ÄúOffices of direct collaboration with the President‚Äù, including the Private Office of the PM (‚ÄúOffice of the President‚Äù). We do not include in our definition: - the offices and departments that report to the Secretary General or to the President of the Council, but have functions that might be carried out by line Ministries. This category includes several offices and departments, supporting the President in specific policy areas (eg. Department of Sport and Tourism, Family Policies, etc.- see below, answer 2.2.1), under the responsibility of a Minister without Portfolio or an Under-Secretary.

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: The main objectives of CoG‚Äôs strategy aimed at improving trust in public institutions are:-	Open government, transparency, integrity, fight against corruption. This objective has been enacted through specific legislative acts, Guidelines and Government Plans.-	Increased participation to the decision making process, e.g through public consultation. For this purpose, a website has been created (www.partecipa.gov.it), with the explicit aim of increasing citizens‚Äô awareness and allowing them to approach the institutions. Among other initiatives, in 2012 a Code of Conduct for Civil Servants has been foreseen (enacted with the Presidential Decree of 16 April 2013, n.62). -	Launch of initiatives aimed at improving services for citizens and enterprises, eliminating unnecessary burdens and easing administrative procedures.-	Promotion of innovation, research and development. -	Merit-based public administrations-	Establishing urgent measures for  the acceleration of public administrations‚Äô payments.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions

Q3.5.1. Does the Centre of Government monitor or measure levels of citizens‚Äô trust in public institutions?
If so, in what way does it monitor trust?
CoG looks at existing opinion polls

No, it neither monitors nor measures trust
Yes, it measures levels of trust
Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: In 2012 the CoG, in cooperation with the Ministry of Internal Affairs, elaborated and the Government approved the Public Management Improvement Programme 2012-2020 and its action plan for 2013 - 2015. The actions to improve the trust in public institutions are also foreseen in the National Development Programmme 2014 - 2020. The NDP identifies 5 priorities one of which is Better Public Management.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions
Q3.6.1. Is the Centre responsible for organising cross-governmental policy co-ordination groups or committees?
If yes, at what level do these groups exist?
Q3.6.2. What other mechanisms are used by the CoG to ensure policy co-ordination (if any)?
Data: Cross cutting planning documents such as annual Government Priorities, Government Programme Action Plan, Cross-cutting Action Plans, Development Programmes (eg. National Development Plan).Annual Government Legislative Programme.Prime Minister's and Government Chancellor's orders.Methodological guidance and recommendations for ministries and Agencies, especially in the area of strategic planning, policy

Topics: Q3.6.3. From 2008-2012, has the number of cross-ministerial policy initiatives
Q3.6.4. What is the role of the CoG in cross-ministerial initiatives?
Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: Financial. Cross-cutting initiatives are encouraged providing additional financial resources for cross-cutting action plans and Government priorities through budget negotiations. Performance targets. Annual Government priorities serve as performance agreemEnts between the Prime Minister and respective minister. Then the minister develops his/her priorities and signs performance agreement with his/ her subordinates (State Secretaries). State Secretary in turn signs annual performance agreement with his/ her subordinates down to individual level. Such performance agreement system was established in 2012.Political support. Annual Government priorities and cross-cutting action plans are discussed and monitored at the Government level. The Government Office ensures on-going coordination and performance information.
Political support for cross-cutting issues at Government level

Topics: Q3.6.6. How much influence can the CoG exert over line ministries to encourage them to coordinate with each other?
Q3.7.1. Through what mechanisms does the CoG ensure that government policies are implemented by line ministries?

Data: Through policy monitoring: - Government Programme Action plan and annual Government priorities - quarterly monitoring of progress and analysis of performance information- benchmarking and systematic evaluation of ministry performance.Facilitation and moderation of problematic issues through working groups and ad hoc meetings.

Topics: Workplan for the implementation of the Government Programme that sets deadlines for ministries to prepare particular proposals
Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: Lithuania's international development and aid policy is being drafted and implemented by MFA. Centre of Government coordinates that policy through the process of budgetary planning and approval.

Topics: Q3.9.1. Please indicate where the co-ordination of relations with each supra- or international body is located.
Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role

Data: For coordination and implementation of strategic planning across the government the Strategic Planning and Monitoring Unit was established in 2000. The Unit, apart from methodological guidance, provides performance information and support to decision making process especially through Government priorities and other cross-cutting issues. The Unit takes the leading role in mobilising ministry staff to identify critical interventions to implement Government priorities and Government Programme.

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: In accordance with the Guidlines there is developed: a legal act on the procedure by which consultations, public involvement and public discussions are organized; a concept paper on financing of political organisations (parties) and the associated legal acts; Guidelines ‚ÄúNational Strategy for Corruption Prevention and Combating for 2009-2013‚Äù  Also:1)	To improve social dialogue, there has been created National Tripartite Cooperation Council -  Members: the Cabinet of Ministers, Employers‚Äô Confederation of Latvia and Free Trade Union Confederation of Latvia2)	To improve civil society participation, there has been created the Council for Implementation of the Cooperation Memorandum between NGOs and the Cabinet of Ministers3)	To reduce the administrative burden and to simplify administrative procedures: 3.1	There has been done researches on specific issues (examples: entrepreneurship, education, healthcare) and proposals have been developed 3.2	To involve the society, there has been created a website to collect the proposalshttp://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktuali/mazinamslogukopa/

The strategy is set in the Guidelines for Public administration development (2008-2013). The 5th target of the guidelines is mostly connected to public involvement and cooperation in public administration.

Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role

Data: To ensure openness and involvement of civil society the meetings of the government are open except cases there are some restricted issues. Real-time agenda of meetings is published on the government web site and the meeting can be watched online http://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktuali/tiesraides/videoarhivs/ or in the archive.We provide a possibility to to receive news about the current events in  the governmentAn electronic management tool is used to organize the work of the governmet meetings. All the documents and necessary information is based in the system ‚Äì e-Portfolio. The users receive  complete set of materials for each agenda of the meeting (agenda, draft, explanatory notes, opinions, minutes)‚Ä¢	3 level authorized access:‚Ä¢	restricted access ‚Äì all information, incl. restricted, only participants of the meeting with voting rights and advisors, interactive‚Ä¢	partial access ‚Äì access to public information, partly interactive‚Ä¢	guest ‚Äì only public information, non-interactiveTo improve civil society participation there has been founded the Council for Implementation of the Cooperation Memorandum between NGOs and the Cabinet of Ministers.To promote a whole-of-government approach the State Chancellery has developed a new performance management system in the public administration. It‚Äôs based on the management by objectives approach (work planning and setting deliverables), appraisal of competencies (competency modules for different groups are offered) and development activities (several development activities to support competencies, career planning). The system favours in the strategic planning (alignment of individual deliverables with the strategic objectives); in future it will be used to introduce a talent management system.

Data: Regarding the potential role played by the CoG in cross-government co-ordination of the international development and aid issues, the CoG does not take part systematically in it. In fact, for some programs, it's the CoG who is directly responsable for coordinating international development issues, it's the case for example of the coop√©ration with Millenium Challenge Corporation, a very important program. For the cooperation with European Union and some bilateral partners in European Union, it's the Ministry of Economy and Finances who is responsable for coordinating international development issues, and in some regard, at the political level, the Ministry of foreign affairs.

Q1.1.1. Does the definition of the term Centre of Government used by this survey correspond to what is considered the ‚Äúcentre of government‚Äù in your country?
Q1.1.2. If your definition of the Centre of Government differs from the definition used in this survey, please explain the difference.
Data: We have defined the Centre of Government as comprising the following two organisations: - Cabinet and Prime Minister‚Äôs Office, which comprises both the Private Office of the Prime Minister and the secretariat of the Cabinet. - Government Information Service, which provides communication support to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet as well as the Head of State. Both of these organisations are part of the Ministry of General Affairs, which also includes several other organisations, such as the Public Information and Communications Service as well as holding political and budgetary responsibility for several others, such as the Scientific Council for Government Policy. These however do not fall within the definition of Centre of Government and are thus not taken into account in the answers to this survey.

Q3.1.1. What are the principal channels through which the Head of Government (HG) discusses policy issues?
Please feel free to provide information on how these channels work
Data: There is both a formal and an informal circuit of Cabinet meetings. The formal circuit involves committee meetings of ministers which take place on a regular basis (for example every other Tuesday, on alternating weeks) in which draft legislation and policy is discussed in more detail prior to the Cabinet meeting which takes place every Friday. There are several different such committee meetings every week, each dealing with a different terrain. Some very broad ‚Äì such as European Union Affairs ‚Äì and others more focused, such as a regular ad hoc meeting dealing with the follow-up to the MH17 plane crash. Such committee meetings are always chaired by the Prime Minister. These formal committee meetings are generally prepared one to two weeks earlier in committee meetings in which the relevant ministries are represented at a civil service level. These committee meetings are not necessarily chaired by a representative of the centre of government, although the chair will always be in close contact with the centre of government. Besides these formal meetings, there is also an informal circuit of meetings in which the Centre of Government plays a varying role, sometimes as a formal or informal chair, and sometimes at some distance.

Q3.2.1. Does the CoG have a social media strategy?
If yes, what are the top 3 goals of this strategy?
Data: 1. Direct policy communication with various groups- more and more people don't use traditional media. Therefor we strive to inform them about government policies through social media.2. Insights in the work of the Prime Minister and the way institutions work. With 'behind the scene'-footage and infographics we try to establish more understanding for the machinery of government.3. InteractionOn occasion we use social media for direct and live interaction between the Prime Minister and some of his followers.

Data: In our day-to-day communications policies we keep a close eye on public trust by working on direct and proactive communication with the public. As CoG, we do not have a special program for improving or maintaining public trust.

Q3.6.1. Is the Centre responsible for organising cross-governmental policy co-ordination groups or committees?

Data: See the answer to question 3.1.1.[channels for discussion policy issues] Besides the formal structure of (sub-)committees, the CoG is entitled to take the initiative to set up ad hoc ministerial committees, as well as ad hoc structures at a civil service level. The CoG plays a central role in these committees, generally providing the chair and/or the secretary.

Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: CoG‚Äôs role is derived from the role the prime minister has as chairman in the ministerial committees and - meetings that deal with these issues. See the prior answers to 3.1.1. [decision-making system] [There is both a formal and an informal circuit of Cabinet meetings. The formal circuit involves committee meetings of ministers which take place on a regular basis (for example every other Tuesday, on alternating weeks) in which draft legislation and policy is discussed in more detail prior to the Cabinet meeting which takes place every Friday. There are several different such committee meetings every week, each dealing with a different terrain. Some very broad ‚Äì such as European Union Affairs ‚Äì and others more focused, such as a regular ad hoc meeting dealing with the follow-up to the MH17 plane crash. Such committee meetings are always chaired by the Prime Minister. These formal committee meetings are generally prepared one to two weeks earlier in committee meetings in which the relevant ministries are represented at a civil service level. These committee meetings are not necessarily chaired by a representative of the centre of government, although the chair will always be in close contact with the centre of government. Besides these formal meetings, there is also an informal circuit of meetings in which the Centre of Government plays a varying role, sometimes as a formal or informal chair, and sometimes at some distance.]

In addition to the aforementioned tasks, the CoG also has a specific responsibility for: - the relationship between the government and the Head of State and the Royal Household; - the coordination of the relationship between the Netherlands and other countries which fall under the Dutch Crown (broadly speaking: the former islands of the Dutch Antilles); - the relationship with the other organisations for which the Ministry of General Affairs has final (political and budgetary) responsibility, such as the Scientific Council for Government Policy; and - the Secretary General of the CoG has a specific role in his responsibility for the coordination of the Security services.

Topics: Q2.2.2. Has the structure of the CoG (number and type of units) remained stable since 2008 or has it changed?
If it has changed, in what way has it changed?
Data: Since 2008, DPMC established an Intelligence Coordination Group, and the National Cyber Policy Office.  SSC‚Äôs main change in this period was to transfer out functions associated with the Government Chief Information Officer and government IT procurement.  HR, IT, Records and Finance functions across the three ministries have been incorporated into a single shared services unit, called the Central Agencies Shared Services, which is located in the Treasury.

Q3.1.1. What are the principal channels through which the Head of Government (HG) discusses policy issues?
Please feel free to provide information on how these channels work
Data: Ministries prepare Cabinet papers for their Minister.  The Minister submits the paper setting out the proposal, which is considered first by a Cabinet committee of Ministers and then either the decisions of the committee or the full proposal will be put to the full Cabinet for final decisions.  Cabinet committees are supported by committees of officials from various ministries, to assist those officials involved in preparing the Cabinet proposal.

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: The State Services Commission's Legal and Integrity Team has a work programme focusing on maintaining and improving the integrity and conduct of State servants, and the public‚Äôs trust in government.  This includes publishing guidance on integrity matters and offering advice in relation to queries and complaints.  In late 2013, this team will run a survey of State servants measuring their perceptions of integrity within the State services.  Results will be published in 2013.

Topics: Q3.6.3. From 2008-2012, has the number of cross-ministerial policy initiatives
Q3.6.4. What is the role of the CoG in cross-ministerial initiatives?
Q3.6.5. What incentives exist to promote co-ordination across ministries/agencies?

Data: FINANCIAL: Financial tools remove barriers to coordination, such as provision for multi-category funding appropriations that allow a lead ministry with a particular task to work with other ministries to deliver on that task.  A ‚Äúseed fund‚Äù has been established to speed up innovative practice by ministries; a key purpose of this fund is to support work to reduce transaction costs and the administrative burden of cross-agency collaboration.INDIVIDUAL/COLLECTIVE PERFORMANCE TARGETS: The Government has agreed 10 result areas that are publicly identified as a priority for the work of the government.  These results span the work of multiple government agencies and so coordination is a necessary key feature.  Performance against these targets is regularly reported to Ministers, and publicly.Coordination is also covered in the performance reviews of the chief executives of ministries ‚Äì in the annual process involving setting expectations and reviewing against those.
The Government has agreed 10 result areas that are publicly identified as a priority for the work of the government.

Workplan for the implementation of the Government Programme that sets deadlines for ministries to prepare particular proposals
Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: DPMC maintains awareness of major Overseas Development Assistance (ODA) proposals and becomes involved in the event that proposals appear to be out of step with New Zealand‚Äôs ODA priorities and/or government policy.

Topics: Q3.9.1. Please indicate where the co-ordination of relations with each supra- or international body is located.
Q3.9.2. Does the Centre of government play a role in international co-operation on policies that require international coordination (e.g. monetary, fi
Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role
Data: The Treasury, in particular, is regularly involved in regional and international forums on issues such as monetary policy, financial regulation, trade and tax (eg APEC and the OECD).  Other government agencies are also involved ‚Äì such as the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment, and the Department of Revenue.

The above information focuses on 2012 and prior.  Since then, the Corporate Centre has incorporated a number of ‚ÄúFunctional Leaders‚Äù that undertake central government functions, but are located within other ministries.  As at August 2013, this comprises three functional leads:‚Ä¢ The Government Chief Information Officer‚Ä¢ The Property Management Centre of Expertise‚Ä¢ The Government Procurement Unit.

Data: "Government office primarily provides a technical and administrative support for Prime minister and government as a whole.Government office is ""Central coordination body"" for implementing EU fund and Swiss, Norwegian and EHP funds as well.Government office is involved in preparing of EU presidency 2016 as well.Competences for Government office and other ministries are given by ""Organization of government activity and orginazation of central state bodies act No. 575/2001.""Under the Goverment office act several ""governmental council"" for different areas (social area, human rights, council for preparing Partnership agreement, etc..) which have no budget."

Data: The Secretariat-General of the Government of the Republic of Slovenia employs a total of 134 people. Around 50 of them are responsible for the organisation and conduct of the sessions of the Government and its working bodies, with others working in government support services (translation, language editing and interpretation, personnel service, finance service, defence preparation and security service, vehicle transport, IT, technical service, main administrative office (couriers) etc.).

Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: In accordance with the International Development Cooperation of the Republic of Slovenia Act, which governs the long-term planning, financing and implementation of the development cooperation of the Republic of Slovenia, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia has set up the Interministerial Working Body for International Development Cooperation, which is tasked with planning, coordination, monitoring, and implementing international development cooperation, discussing estimated funds for international development cooperation etc. The Interministerial Working Body, the members of which are representatives of all ministries and the Office of the Prime Minister, is headed by a representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (the ministry responsible for this area).

Please describe in more detail the CoG‚Äôs role

Data: The Secretariat-General of the Government is responsible for: organising sessions of the Government, its working bodies, strategic councils and other Governmental bodies; monitoring the implementation of resolutions adopted by the Government and obligations taken on or assigned to the Government; the participation of the Government or its representatives in the sessions of the National Assembly, cooperation with the President of the RS and other state bodies and organisations, and cooperation with other states and international organisations; ensuring the availability of opinions and other materials necessary for the formation of policy standpoints by the Government and its working bodies; the organisation and activities of Government offices whose directors report to the Government Secretary-General; other matters necessary for the functioning of the Government, its working bodies and councils, as well as those Government offices whose directors report to the Government Secretary-General. The Secretariat-General of the Government also provides translation and editing services and transport by car for the ministries, for the Office of the Prime Minister and for the Government Offices.  The Secretariat-General of the Government carries out the following professional, administrative and technical tasks for the Office of the Prime Minister: managing the financial affairs of the Office of the Prime Minister and the maintenance of its premises; information and documentation activities; the regulation of employee rights and working conditions; postal, courier, printing and photocopying services.The Secretariat-General of the Government is very successful in its role of coordination and cooperation however is understaffed for comprehensive and in-depth coordination and monitoring.

Q3.8.1. Is there a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination, coherence or discussion of international development and aid issues?

Data: The responsibility of ensuring coherence in international development and aid lies within the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, not the CoG. However, as answered in 3.6.2, the CoG sets guidelines for the procedures used when preparing government decisions, that is a mechanism for cross-government co-ordination etc. Working procedures are set to mirror the fact that the government takes decisions collectively.

Q3.5.2. Does CoG have a strategy or taken any actions directly aimed at improving or maintaining trust in public institutions?

Data: In the aftermatch of EU-Turkey talks around 1995, the then Turkish prime minister established the ‚ÄòEconomic and Social Council‚Äô in 1995 and started its activities in 1997. The council should meet quarterly, on the invitation of the president. The president can call for extra meetings. Duties: To advise to government on various economic and social matters that are related to the economic and social life, To ensure the participation of the various social partners in the governmental economic and social policies. To promote consensus and cooperation both between the government and these groups and among these groups themselves. To submit opinions, views and reports to the Government, the Parliament, the President and the public, on its own referral. To establish, continual and provisional labour boards.

Topics: Further comments on trust in public institutions
Data: On this issue, Turkey Prime Ministry Inspection Board has adopted a 2010-2014 strategy for Enhancing Transparency and Strengthening the Fight against Corruption in February 2010. ‚ÄúCommission for Increasing Transparency and Struggle against Corruption in Turkey (Commission)‚Äù which consists of the Deputy Prime Minister and five ministers (Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Interior, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Labour and Social Security, Ministry of Customs and Trade) was established in December 2009 together with an executive board made up of representatives of public institutions, labour unions and the Turkish Union of Chambers and Stock Exchanges (TOBB) to form further anti-corruption strategies and to direct and monitor their implementation.‚ÄúStrategy for Increasing Transparency and Struggle Against Corruption (The Strategy)‚Äù approved by first Executive Board and later Commission. Strategy in question, No 2010/56 was adopted by Council of Ministers and published in Official Journal in 22/02/2010. The strategy aims at developing preventive and repressive measures against corruption and improving public governance by introducing more transparency, accountability and trust in the public administration. An action plan setting the timetables for adoption and implementation of each measure prepared by Execution Committee was approved by the ministerial commission in April 2010. The Fundamental components of the Strategy that will be realized between the years 2010-2014 are gathered under 3 main titles as the measures for;        	A) Prevention,        	B) Applying Sanction         	C) Increasing Public Awareness There are 28 preventative measures under these 3 main titles. In order to realize these measures 23 working groups has been generated and 243 persons have been appointed at those groups.Executive Committee has gathered 25 times, reviewed 25 reports prepared by relevant working groups and made decisions about 23 measures. Temporarily out of representatives of NGO‚Äôs invited, 43 of the representative of the NGO and private sector representatives has been appointed in working groups as a permanent. On 19/08/2011 these decisions approved by Ministerial Commission, the working groups will continue to work on those measures. After the approval of the Commission, the recommendations in the reports of the working groups were tried to regulations and legislation, as a result of the five meetings of the Executive Board three of them were eligible.These three measures are as follows;1.Development of applications about openness and transparency on the financing of political parties and election campaigns and activate supervision2.Informing citizens about the opportunity to apply authorities and the rights has given by laws and administrative regulations when they face with an unfair practice3.Conducting corruption perception survey at regular intervalsThe other measures achieved are below;1.The establishment of Ombudsman2.Court of Accounts Law AmendmentThe legal process has been completed and the applications have started. The current situation was evaluated by Ministerial Commission on 29/03/2013. According to evaluation that all working group‚Äôs reports which are 23 in total will be evaluated by the time September, 2013 by Executive Committee, then the decision made by Executive Committee will be submitted to the Commission for approval on October 2013.This Strategy is prepared to increase institutional capacity against corruption, which adversely affects the social life, corrodes moral values, severely damages citizen's trust in public institutions, and to increase transparency. With the realization of the measures of the Strategy the purpose is to develop a more just, accountable, transparent and reliable administrative mentality and preventing inclination to corruption crimes trough increased awareness about corruption, thus increasing the effectiveness of the system.

Q3.3.1. Is there a document outlining a long-term strategic vision for the country?
If yes, to whom is the strategic vision document made available?
If yes, what institution monitors its implementation?
Data: Depending on the policy or strategy, if may be monitored by a component within the EOP (often the Office of Management and Budget), Performance Improvement Council (for Cross-Agency and Agency Priority Goals) or another Executive Branch Agency.

Topics: If yes, how far in the future does it cover?

Data: There are multiple documents that help achieve this purpose. The opening chapters of the President‚Äôs Budget provide much of that long-term vision.  Agency strategic plans also supplement this in more detail.  Policy areas release cross-cutting long-term plans on major issues (e.g. National Security Strategy, Energy Blueprint, Plan to End Homelessness).  Recently, Cross-Agency Priority Goals (e.g. Double US Exports) have been identified to establish a limited number of specific measurable goals that cut across multiple agencies. Each of these efforts is prepared using collaboration shared between Executive Office of the President and other Executive Branch Agencies.
